newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS - AT&T LEAPS ahead of split.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS - AT&T LEAPS ahead of split.

text.p: Early options trading was highlighted by a trade in three January 1998 options on AT&T Corp, which some analysts said could be related to the company's breakup.
The January 1998 55 call, 60 call and 55 put each traded 1,000 contracts within the first half hour of trading. The stock was unchanged at 52-1/2.
Those long-term options are known as LEAPS, or long-term equity anticipation securities.
Traders said a customer sold the options with the expectation the shares would hold between 45 and 65.
The January 1998 55 call had a premium of 4-1/2, the 55 put had a premium of 5-1/4 and the 60 call had a premium of 2-3/4.
Harrison Roth, options strategist at Cowen & Co, said the options writer took in a total of 12-1/2 points, giving him protection on the stock down to 42-1/2.
"I think he's relatively safe there," Roth said. "On the upside, he has an uncovered call in the January 60s, but he's pretty safe on that.
"It's not a bad trade," he said.

Michael Schwartz, a managing director at Oppenheimer & Co, said the investor could be positioning for the split-up of AT&T, which will break off its Lucent Technologies Inc unit at the end of September.
"They're positioning themselves on options that will be readjusted to reflect Telephone and Lucent," he said.
